title: Mutual Funds & ETFs
description: Understand mutual funds and ETFs, learn how to select funds based on goals, and build diversified portfolios.
objectives: Understand structure and types of mutual funds
Learn about ETFs and their advantages
Analyze fund performance metrics (NAV, expense ratio, returns)
Select funds based on investment goals and risk profile

lessons.title: Mutual Funds Explained
lessons.videoTopic: What are Mutual Funds and How They Work

content.original: Mutual fund pools money from multiple investors to invest in diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds, or other securities. Managed by professional fund managers. NAV (Net Asset Value) = Total portfolio value / Number of units. Types: Equity funds (stocks), Debt funds (bonds), Hybrid funds (mix). Open-ended funds allow daily buy/sell, closed-ended have fixed tenure. SIP (Systematic Investment Plan) enables disciplined monthly investing.
content.simplified: Mutual fund is like a basket where many investors put their money together. Expert fund manager then invests this big pool in many different stocks/bonds. You buy units of the fund. If fund's investments grow, your unit value (NAV) increases. Types: Equity funds (higher risk, higher return), Debt funds (lower risk, stable return), Hybrid (balanced). You can invest monthly small amounts through SIP instead of big lumpsum.

lessons.aiSummary: Mutual Fund = Pooled investment vehicle. Fund manager invests in diversified portfolio. NAV = Fund value per unit. Types: Equity, Debt, Hybrid. SIP = Monthly disciplined investing.
keyTakeaways: Mutual funds offer instant diversification for small investors
Professional management by experienced fund managers
SIP helps average out market volatility (rupee cost averaging)
Can start with as little as ‚Çπ500/month
commonMistakes: Choosing fund based on past 1-year return (too short-term)
Stopping SIP when market falls (best time to accumulate units)
Holding too many funds (over-diversification reduces returns)

lessons.title: ETFs - Exchange Traded Funds

content.original: ETF = Exchange Traded Fund, trades on stock exchange like shares. Tracks index (Nifty 50 ETF mirrors Nifty 50). Passive investment - no active fund manager. Advantages: Lower expense ratio (0.05-0.25% vs 1-2% in mutual funds), intraday trading, high transparency. Nifty BeES, Sensex ETF, Gold BeES are popular. Buy through demat account. Ideal for long-term passive investors. Dividend yield higher in ETFs.
content.simplified: ETF is like a mutual fund but trades on stock exchange like a regular share. Most ETFs simply copy an index - if you buy Nifty ETF, you're buying all 50 Nifty companies automatically. Much cheaper than active mutual funds because no fund manager is actively picking stocks. You can buy/sell anytime during market hours just like stocks. Great for beginners who want diversification without complexity.

lessons.aiSummary: ETF = Index-tracking fund traded on exchange. Passive investment. Benefits: Low cost (0.05-0.25% expense), intraday trading, transparency. Ideal for long-term passive strategy. Buy via demat account.
keyTakeaways: ETFs have 5-10x lower expense ratio than active mutual funds
Liquidity: Can buy/sell anytime during market hours
Transparency: Holdings disclosed daily (vs monthly in MFs)
No exit load in ETFs (unlike some mutual funds)
commonMistakes: Trading ETFs frequently (defeats long-term purpose, adds costs)
Confusing ETFs with stocks (ETF is basket of many stocks)
Ignoring tracking error (how closely ETF follows index)

lessons.title: Evaluating Fund Performance
lessons.videoTopic: NAV, Expense Ratio, Returns, Sharpe Ratio Analysis

content.original: Key metrics: (1) Rolling returns (3yr, 5yr) more reliable than point-to-point. (2) Expense ratio - lower is better, aim <1% for equity, <0.5% for index funds. (3) Sharpe ratio - risk-adjusted returns, higher better. (4) Alpha - excess return over benchmark. (5) Beta - volatility relative to market. Compare with benchmark and category average. Consistent performance across market cycles matters more than 1-year stellar return. Check fund manager tenure and philosophy.
content.simplified: How to judge if mutual fund is good: (1) Check 3-year and 5-year returns, not just last year. (2) Lower expense ratio = more money stays in your pocket (prefer <1%). (3) Compare with benchmark index - if Nifty gave 12% and fund gave 10%, fund underperformed. (4) Look for consistency - fund should perform well in both bull and bear markets. (5) Check how long fund manager has been managing (longer = more experience with same fund).

lessons.aiSummary: Evaluation metrics: Rolling returns (3yr, 5yr), Expense ratio (<1% equity, <0.5% index), Sharpe ratio (risk-adjusted return), Alpha (excess return), Beta (volatility). Consistency > short-term performance.
keyTakeaways: Don't chase last year's best performer (mean reversion)
Lower expense ratio = higher net returns over time
3-5 year track record minimum for evaluation
Compare fund with appropriate benchmark (large-cap fund vs Nifty 100)
commonMistakes: Selecting fund based only on 1-year return (recency bias)
Ignoring expense ratio (1% vs 2% = huge difference over 20 years)
Not checking fund manager changes (different manager = different strategy)

lessons.title: Choosing Funds for Goals

content.original: Goal-based investing framework: Short-term goals (<3 years) ‚Üí Liquid/Ultra-short debt funds. Medium-term (3-5 years) ‚Üí Hybrid funds/Balanced Advantage. Long-term (>5 years) ‚Üí Equity funds. Within equity: Large-cap for stability, Mid/Small-cap for growth (higher risk). Index funds for passive, Active funds for alpha generation. Tax: LTCG >‚Çπ1.25L taxed at 12.5%, STCG at 20%. SIP in equity funds ideal for wealth creation. Emergency fund in liquid funds.
content.simplified: Match fund type to your goal timeline: Need money in 1-2 years (house down payment, car purchase) ‚Üí Use debt funds (safe, stable). Goal is 3-5 years away (child's school admission) ‚Üí Use balanced/hybrid funds (moderate risk). Long-term goals 7+ years (retirement, child's college) ‚Üí Use equity funds (higher returns over long period). For long-term equity, start SIP and stay invested through ups and downs. Keep 6-month expenses in liquid fund as emergency backup.

lessons.aiSummary: Goal-based selection: <3yr ‚Üí Debt funds, 3-5yr ‚Üí Hybrid, >5yr ‚Üí Equity. Equity types: Large-cap (stable), Mid/small-cap (growth). Index funds (passive), Active (alpha). Tax: LTCG 12.5% above ‚Çπ1.25L.
keyTakeaways: Time horizon determines asset allocation
Never invest in equity for short-term needs
Index funds suit most investors (lower cost, market returns)
Review portfolio annually, rebalance if needed
commonMistakes: Investing in equity funds for short-term goal (high risk of loss)
Putting emergency fund in equity (liquidity crisis when market down)
Not aligning fund risk with personal risk tolerance

lessons.title: Building Mutual Fund Portfolio

content.original: Core-Satellite approach: Core (70%) in index funds/large-cap equity for stability. Satellite (30%) in mid-cap/sectoral for alpha. Asset allocation example: 60% equity, 30% debt, 10% gold (varies by age and risk profile). Younger investors can have 80-90% equity. Rule of thumb: Equity % = 100 - Age. Rebalance annually to maintain allocation. Avoid overlap - check portfolio holdings. 3-5 funds sufficient for most investors. SIP amount should be 20-30% of monthly income if possible.
content.simplified: Smart portfolio structure: Put majority (70%) in safe, reliable index funds that track Nifty/Sensex. Put smaller portion (30%) in funds that aim to beat market. Spread money across different types: If you're young, can go aggressive (80% equity, 20% debt). If near retirement, be conservative (40% equity, 60% debt). Simple rule: Your age = how much percent should be in safe debt funds. Review once a year and adjust. Don't buy too many funds - 3 to 5 is enough.

Index funds should form core of equity allocation
Asset allocation more important than fund selection
Automate SIPs to ensure discipline
commonMistakes: Never rebalancing (portfolio drift from target allocation)
Stopping SIP during market crash (best buying opportunity)
